Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Bellman function, Harmonic Analysis and Operator Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract (Volberg/Nazarov/Treil: 0758552/0800243/0800876)

The proposed research is at the intersection of Geometric Measure Theory and Harmonic Analysis. The main objective of Geometric Measure Theory is to find structures in seemingly unstructured, fractal-like patterns. The classical Harmonic Analysis studies wave propagation, and investigation of singular integral operators is a crucial part of the modern approach. Our continuing research, as well as the work of several other groups of mathematicians in the US and abroad, has demonstrated that new knowledge can be obtained by exploring the interaction between these two areas.

As a result of our proposal we expect to solve several important problems in Geometric Measure Theory as well as in Harmonic Analysis. The pattern recognition (i.e., problems in Geometric Measure Theory) would be advanced by using methods originating in Harmonic Analysis, and vice versa. We also expect to develop new methods to study both patterns and waves. It is expected that these newly developed techniques will have impact to adjacent areas of engineering and computer sciences such as image processing and data compression.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the reporting period, the research of the PI was primarily related to the David-Semmes conjecture on the relationship between the boundedness of the s-dimensional Riesz transform and the geometric properties of the underlying measure. The question itself is over 20 years old and is one of the central in the theory of Calderon-Zygmund operators with applications to the free boundary problem and the estimates for the harmonic measure in domains with rough boundaries. The PI and his collaborators were successful in establishing the validity of the conjecture in a certain range of parameters that was intractable before though, unfortunately, the full resolution is still evasive. Several new tools have been introduced into the field, reviving the interest of the harmonic analysis community in this particular line of research and giving the hope for further progress. Two postdocs and one graduate student were partially supported by the award and trained within the scope of this project. The work of the PI was done in collaboration with several people, including the Spanish team led by Xavier Tolsa, who is currently the primary expert on the subject. This established and reinforced close ties between the American and the Spanish teams working in the area. Several joint papers have been published or are in preparation.
